snippet.title: Juppon Gatana - Sega Fish Life [Exclusive Close up] (ENG)
snippet.description:
Press here for more information!

√  Versión en Español del Video: https://youtu.be/lE75UeWSmZ8


Released in June, 2000. This console was built in order to be a virtual aquarium for hotels, restaurants, bars and others that couldn’t (or wouldn’t) have a real aquarium, it also offered a different kind of entertainment for visitors. 
The release price was 498,000 Yen for the console (about $6,500 by the 2000’s), while the game costed 198,000 Yen. A few games were made and these featured different fish and environments in each one of them.

Fish Life consists of two parts; the HKS-0200, the main unit, based on Dreamcast Hardware, uses the same GD-ROM storage format for software and acts as a basis for the other part, the HKS-0100, a 15-inch touch screen monitor with sound recognition. This monitor allowed you to interact with the fish in a lot of ways: such as talking to them, poking them to make them swell, feed them and also have them turn into musical notes that you can press to make music; you can draw a fish of your own on the screen too and it will immediately start swimming around with the others.

There’s no official information on how many units were made but judging by the times a Sega Fish Life has been seen, we can presume there weren’t many.

Thanks for watching!
